awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Building Secure Decentralized Applications with Trusted Hardware and Blockchains
awd_abstract_narration:
This project explores a new, integrated approach to securing decentralized applications.  The key problem is that decentralized applications are executed by mutually distrusting entities in a decentralized distributed system (such as a blockchain), where the entities must collaborate to execute the desired computation, despite not trusting each other.  Building decentralized applications is difficult and error prone because the low-level security mechanisms are too removed from the high-level policies, thus it is difficult for programmers to correctly implement the policies. In these cases, no single entity is trusted to fully specify or enforce security policies. The project will develop Flame, a programming language offering more precise abstractions for expressing security intent in decentralized systems. Using Flame gives developers assurance that their programs are both secure and realizable without requiring them to design and implement complex security protocols.  This project will also develop Decent, a decentralized runtime platform for executing decentralized applications built with Flame. The project will open-source Flame and Decent and promote them with publications, tutorials, and course materials. 

To explore a new, integrated approach to enforce end-to-end security for decentralized applications the project will build a prototype based on techniques for decentralized information flow control, blockchain networks, trusted computing, and cryptography to create a high-level programming layer that eases the task of building, verifying, and deploying decentralized applications.  The prototype will support policies that cannot be enforced in current information control models and are too difficult to realize with cryptographic and access control mechanisms alone.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Decentralized information security is concerned with enforcing the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of information in systems where no single entity is trusted to specify or enforce security policies. Decentralized systems like the Internet and blockchains are increasingly common as corporations and individuals find new ways to interact electronically, even when those they interact with may be untrustworthy.
This project created new approaches to secure distributed programming that made it easier and less error-prone to create secure applications.  There were three primary research directions pursued by this project:

1. Developing new programming abstractions for decentralized security mechanisms that help guarantee the security of implementations.

2. Extending security foundations with more expressive policies and semantic guarantees to characterize the security of more realistic applications that often do not fit into simplified formal models.

3. Building an integrated runtime platform that helps programmers build secure decentralized applications faster and with fewer security vulnerabilities.

Over the course of the project, these activities produced several significant results both foundational and practical in nature.

Artifacts: 

1. Flame: A Haskell library and compiler plugin for enforcing information flow control with Flow-Limited Authorization.

2. Decent / Decentagram: An application framework for building minimum-trust decentralization applications with Trusted Execution Environments and blockchain smart contracts.

3. Phoenix: A distributed systems protocol to increase the recoverability Byzantine Fault tolerant services automatically.

Full details of these projects and more can be found in the relevant publications produced over the course of the project. 

The broader impacts this award include the publication and presentation of seven peer-reviewed research papers, and the results of the project form the partial basis for two doctoral theses, as well as several independent research projects by undergraduate and masters students. Many of these students currenlty (or plan to) pursue further graduate study or have security-related roles in industry.  Recruiting a diverse group of students was a goal and priority for this project: students supported by or participating in this grant come from groups historically marginalized by academia, specifically including first generation students, women, and LGBTQ+.
